column1: #Text=The Parliament of Finland has voted 105 to 92 today to approve a citizen 's initiative to legalise same-sex marriage .
#Text=The law now makes marriage gender-neutral and extends adoption rights and the right to use the same surname to same-sex couples .
#Text=Prime Minister Alexander Stubb supported the change to the law .
#Text=" Finland should strive to become a society where discrimination does not exist , human rights are respected and two adults can marry regardless of their sexual orientation .

#Text= Following the vote , Stubb said he was " sincerely happy that marriage equality , gender equality and human rights prevailed in this issue .

_	_	_	_

#Text=Stubb also noted the citizen 's initiative process that led to the law being considered by Parliament is  important " and " a demonstration of civic activism .

#Text=Mika Niikko from the Finns Party said ,  This is a question of the future of our children and the whole society , and such changes should not be made without thorough evaluation of their impact .

_	_	_	_

#Text=Interior Minister Päivi Räsänen from the Christian Democrats Party said the vote represented a  deep question of principle " and " in the future a large group of Finns will continue to consider marriage to be a bond between a man and a woman , and that they will not consider relationships between people of the same gender to be marriages .

#Text=In contrast , Archbishop Kari Mäkinen from the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland welcomed the change :  I know how much this day means to the rainbow community , their loved ones and many others .

_	_	_	_

#Text=Archbishop Mäkinen had previously stated :  If the initiative is passed , no one 's marriage will lose any of its value , nor will the position of a single child be endangered .

_	_	_	_

#Text=The future treatment of weddings by the Evangelical Lutheran Church has not yet been determined .
